definition: to fight at the head of one's troops/(fig.) to take the lead
body/life/oneself/personally/one's morality and conduct/the main part of a structure or body/pregnant/classifier for sets of clothes: suit, twinset/Kangxi radical 158
member of the senior ministerial class (old)/scholar (old)/bachelor/honorific/soldier/noncommissioned officer/specialist worker
soldier/servant/to finish/to die/finally/at last/pawn in Chinese chess

sentences.english: No matter what you do, as a leader, must take the lead.
sentences.chinese: 不管做什麼事，作爲一名領導者，都必須身先士卒。

sentences.english: Aries pushes the others aside to get to the door first.
sentences.chinese: 白羊座身先士卒，第一個闖進屋門。

sentences.english: This time, lead the Yellow Emperor, to lead troops reached the Chiyou array.
sentences.chinese: 這次，黃帝身先士卒，帶兵殺入蚩尤陣中。

sentences.english: Now they are mandating that Geico develop a commanding presence on mobile phones.
sentences.chinese: 現在他們正身先士卒地將Geico開拓到手機上。

definition: dauntless/to summon up courage and determination/using extreme force of will
to charge and break through enemy lines
bravery with no thought of personal safety (idiom); risking life and limb/undaunted by perils
to be brave and good at fighting (idiom)
to fight with all one's might
